channel.title: Mastodon Home Timeline
channel.description: RSS feed for the Mastodon Home timeline

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: An interview with Elaine Fuchs.https://youtu.be/EWaMXZFQyn0We talk about stem cell niches in the skin, tissue regeneration and how skin cell chromatin remembers stress experienced.Elaine foresees a time when the concept of "memory" extends beyond neurons.

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: How do you grow embryos outside the womb?Jacob Hanna and I discuss his amazing progress in "stembryology". We talk about the uterine barrier, blending stem cells, the necessary incubation conditions, and going beyond gastrulation in mice and humans. https://youtu.be/fiTKdAQGsDI

item.title: Richard Sever
item.description: An interview with Sean Morrisonhttps://youtu.be/BK1RyNS5u7MSean is optimistic that stem research is delivering on its promises with new treatments for various diseases and a host of new factors and mechanisms identified. He also discuses his recent work on leptin-receptor-positive cells in bone marrow and regulation of innervation by NGF, which might have interesting implications for older patients on beta blockers.

item.title: Carl Zimmer
item.description: Did a small-brained hominin bury its dead in graves, make engravings on cave walls, & master fire? Here's my story on extraordinary claims about the fascinating Homo naledi (& the skeptical reaction from experts) https://www.nytimes.com/2023/06/05/science/ancient-humans-homo-naledi-buried-dead.html

item.title: Alessio Buccino
item.description:
Do you use #neuropixels or #highdensity probes? Are your recordings filling up your hard drives?
We got you covered!In the first preprint from
@AllenInstitute
for Neural Dynamics, we looked at ways to reduce the footprint of #ephys data.https://www.biorxiv.org/content/10.1101/2023.05.22.541700v2(1/n)

item.title: Alessio Buccino
item.description:
Finally, kudos to all co-authors!
Olivier Winter, David Bryant, David Feng, @svoboda314 and Josh Siegle, and thanks to
@alleninstitute for sponsoring this work! (12/n)

item.title: PLOS Biology
item.description: Why have we not yet solved the challenge of plastic degradation by biological means?Learn more about the science of #plastic biodegradation to help #BeatPlasticPollution on #WorldEnvironmentDay2023 https://plos.io/3IWbVuh

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: A #nyc street corner for #photography #Fotomontag #Photomonday

item.title: Nabeel Siddiqui
item.description: @sharoz The Python community is not really focused as much on statistical analysis but on industry pipelines. There are often major contributors that have little statistical knowledge. I am sure that this has changed over time, and I don't really mind if someone uses one over the other. However, this reddit thread and its links are worth checking out: https://www.reddit.com/r/statistics/comments/8de54s/comment/dxmnaef/?utm_source=share&utm_medium=web2x&context=3

item.title: flypapers
item.description:
📰 "split-intein Gal4 provides intersectional genetic labeling that is repressible by Gal80"
by 🔬 Ben Ewen-Campen, Haojiang Luan, Jun Xu, Rohit Singh, Neha Joshi, Tanuj Thakkar, Bonnie Berger, Benjamin H White, Norbert Perrimon
https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/37276389/ #Drosophila

item.title: Lot_49
item.description: "Dunning-Krugerand" is the best imaginable name for Bitcoin.

item.title: Grace Lindsay
item.description:
Interesting piece on #ClimateChange anxiety and the need to actually do something rather than just learn coping mechanisms (arguably this could be true for many forms of anxiety but I am particularly interested in people using their anxiety as a motivator to act on the #ClimateCrisis )
https://www.nature.com/articles/s41558-023-01617-4

item.title: Grace Lindsay
item.description: Basically, if you feel anxiety about climate change, yes, you *should* be changing something (probably multiple things) about your life.

item.title: David Schoppik
item.description: #NYC is looking particularly grim this evening. Hard to catch a photo that conveys the eerie feeling but here are #OneVanderbilt, the #ChrysterBuilding and the #EmpireStateBuilding for y'all. The sky isn't normally gray. #photography #climatechange #wildfires #ocanada

item.title: Diane 🕵
item.description: @schoppik I remember during the Northern California fires people had a tough time getting cell phone photographs that reflected what they saw because the phone kept correcting away from how weird it looked to the human eye.

item.title: Cian O’Donnell
item.description: Please advertise our 3rd annual Autumn School onComputational Neuroscience, Neurotechnology and Neuro-inspired AI25th-31st Oct 2023in Ulster University, Derry/Londonderry, Northern IrelandHybrid in-person/onlinehttps://www.ulster.ac.uk/faculties/computing-engineering-and-the-built-environment/computing-engineering-intelligent-systems/isrc-cn3-autumn-school

item.title: Nicole Rust
item.description:
Favorite books/refs/talks on the role of metaphor in scientific discovery?There's Lakoff/Johnson
Metaphors we live by
https://press.uchicago.edu/ucp/books/book/chicago/M/bo3637992.htmlWhat else? Anyone read this?
Making Truth
Metaphor in Science
Theodore L. Brown
https://www.press.uillinois.edu/books/?id=p075827

item.title: Eric's Risk Assessment
item.description:
Risk of #LongCovid at 10% on first infection, rising to 20% on second.There is nothing you do voluntarily that has this level of risk. Not flying, not skydiving, not driving.US National Institutes of Health Study Finds Increased Risk of Long Covid After Reinfection
https://johnsnowproject.org/primers/nih-study-finds-increased-risk-of-long-covid-after-reinfection/>Study shows risk of Long Covid is very common after Omicron reinfection, but is anyone listening?#sars2 #SARSCoV2

item.title: Terence Tao
item.description: The #NationalAcademies of Science, Engineering, and Medicine is hosting a virtual workshop on the topic of "AI to assist mathematical reasoning": https://www.nationalacademies.org/event/06-12-2023/ai-to-assist-mathematical-reasoning-a-workshop , to be held June 12-14. (I am one of the members of the organising committee). Registration for the workshop is now open, and the schedule of speakers and panelists is now available. We plan to follow up on this workshop with an in person event later this year.

item.title: Jess Butler
item.description: Superb journalism in El País todayManuel Ansede looked at the publications of Spain's top academics and found scams upon scamsHe didn't find a few bad apples, but institutionalised cheating for metrics"Spanish universities have become veritable “factory farms” for insubstantial studies...data shows that, in 2015, barely 0.9% of Spanish production was published in MDPI journals...Six years later, the percentage in Spain shot up to nearly 15%"https://english.elpais.com/science-tech/2023-06-04/a-researcher-who-publishes-a-study-every-two-days-reveals-the-darker-side-of-science.html
